children.name: for sale a2
children.definition: for sale/fəʳ ˈseɪl/  if something is for sale, the person who owns it wants to sell it:
examples: để bán
▪ there are several houses for sale in our street.
▪ there was ‘for sale’ notice in the car’s window.
▪ the festival will have food and crafts for sale, games for children, and music.
for sale để bán
available to buy
_is this painting for sale?
_our neighboursputtheir houseupfor sale (= started to advertise that they want to sell it) last week.

children.name: on sale b1
children.definition: on sale/biː ɒn ˈseɪl/  if a product is on sale, you can buy it in the shops:
examples: được bán
▪ these cameras are on sale in most electrical stores.go on sale begin to be available
▪ the new model toyota goes on sale next month.
on saleuk sẵn sàng để bán; có bán
available to buy in a shop
_on sale at record stores now.

children.name: on the market x
children.definition: on the market/ɒn ðə ˈmɑːʳkt/  goods that are on the market are available for people to buy -use this especially when you are comparing products of the same general type:
examples: được bán trên thị trường
▪ it’s one of the cheapest computers on the market.
▪ there may be better shoes on the market, but this is the one the kids want.
on the market for
▪ the house was on the market for $475,000.

children.name: up for sale a2
children.definition: be up for sale/biː ˌʌp fəʳ ˈseɪl/  if something such as a house, a shop, or a piece of land is up for sale, it has been publicly announced that it is available for people to buy:
examples: được rao bán
▪ the house has been up for sale for months.
▪ several subsidiary businesses are up for sale.

children.name: when a lot of sth is sold
sell a2
children.definition: sell/sel/
examples: bán được
▪ books that don’t sell are sent back to the publishers.
▪ the handcrafted rocking horses have sold well across the united states.
▪ the last model didn’t sell as well as they’d expected.

children.name: best-selling x
children.definition: best-selling/ˌbest ˈselɪŋ◂/a best-selling product is one that is sold in large numbers, especially more than any other product of the same type:
examples: bán chạy
▪ agatha christie is said to be the world’s best-selling author.
▪ a list of the wegytgek’s best-selling music and children’s videos
▪ chanel number 5 is the best-selling scent of all time.

children.name: best-seller b2
children.definition: best-seller /bestseller/best seller/ˌbest ˈseləʳ/  a book, game, video, record etc that has been bought by a very large number of people:
examples: ▪ several tv movies have been based on best sellers by danielle steel.
▪ every year there’s a toy that becomes a hard-to-find best-seller.
bestseller listan official list of what has sold most
▪ all four harry potter books are currently on the bestseller list.

children.name: outsell x
children.definition: outsell/aʊtˈsel/  if one product outsells another, more of it is sold than the other product:
examples: bán chạy hơn
▪ his latest album has outsold all his other records put together.
▪ chardonnay continues to outsell other wines.
outsellverb[ t ]outsold,outsold stbán chạy hơnst
(of a product) to be sold in greater numbers than another product
_cds soon began to outsell records.

children.name: be selling like hot cakes c2
children.definition: be selling like hot cakes/biː ˌselɪŋ laɪk ˌhɒt ˈkeɪksǁ-ˌhɑːt-/  informal if a product is selling like hot cakes, it is being sold very quickly and in large amounts because people very much want to buy it:
examples: ▪ grisham’s new book is selling like hot cakes.
go/sell like hot cakesinformal
to be bought quickly and in large numbers
_his new video game is apparently selling like hot cakes.

children.name: do a roaring trade x
children.definition: do a roaring trade/duː ə ˌrɔːrɪŋ ˈtreɪd/  british if a shop or a person that sells a particular type of goods is doing a roaring trade, they are selling large quantities of goods because a lot of people suddenly want to buy them:
examples: ▪ since the heatwave started, ice cream vendors have been doing a roaring trade.
do a roaring trade in
▪ the shops outside the station were doing a roaring trade in umbrellas.

children.name: sell a2
children.definition: sell/sel/  to give something to someone in exchange for money:
examples: ▪ tom’s thinking of selling his motorcycle and buying a new one.
▪ if you can, wait to sell until prices are high.
▪ postcards and souvenirs were being sold outside the cathedral.
sell somebody something
▪ the company sold braugh $100,000 worth of computers at discounted rates.
sell something to somebody
▪ it is illegal to sell tobacco to anyone under the age of 18.
▪ the painting was sold to an art gallery in philadelphia.
sell something for £250/$50 etc
▪ the antique buttons are very valuable, and we sell them for £100 and upwards.
sellverbsold,soldmoney bán
[ i or t ] to give something to someone else in return for money
_[ + two objects]i sold him my car/i sold my car to himfor£600.
_we'll be selling the ticketsat/for£50 each.
_the stall sells drinks and snacks.
_these baskets sell well (= a lot of them are bought) .

children.name: export b2
children.definition: export/ɪkˈspɔːʳt/  if a country or a company exports its products, it sends them to another country in order to sell them:
examples: ▪ japanese televisions and hi-fi systems are exported all over the world.
▪ ancient artefacts cannot be exported.
export something to france/the uk/japan etc
▪ in 1986 they exported 210,000 cases of wine to the uk.
exporter[countable noun]
▪ saudi arabia is one of the world’s leading exporters of oil.
export[adjective only before noun]
▪ export earnings are lower than last year.
exportverb xuất khẩu
[ i or t ] to send goods to another country for sale
_french cheeses are exportedtomany different countries.
_our clothes sell so well in this country that we have no need to export.

children.name: sell off x
children.definition: sell off /ˌsel ˈɒf/  to sell something, usually a group of things, at a reduced price in order to get rid of it quickly, because you need the money soon, or because it will not last a long time:
examples: bán hạ giá
sell something off
▪ the bakery usually sells its cakes off at half price just before closing time.
sell off something
▪ after the funeral the house contents were sold off quickly to pay all his debts.
▪ the school district may be forced to close schools and sell off land in order to make much-needed repairs.
sellsthoffphrasal verb[ m ]
to charge a low price for something to encourage people to buy it
_they're selling off last year's stock at half price.

children.name: sell up x
children.definition: sell up/ˌsel ˈʌp/  british to sell your house, your business, or other things you ownin order to move to a different place or to do something different:
examples: bán sạch, bán hết
▪ why don’t we sell up and move to canada? property is really cheap there!
▪ my parents sold up the farm and went to live in glasgow.

children.name: serve b1
children.definition: serve/sɜːʳv/  if someone who works in a shop or a bar serves a customer, they help them to buy or choose the goods that they want:
examples: ▪ there was a line of people in front of me who were all waiting to be served.
▪ estrada was serving a customer when the fire started.
▪ it is illegal to serve alcoholic drinks to anyone under 18.
serveverbdeal with customer
[ t ] in a shop, restaurant or hotel, to deal with a customer by taking their order,showing or selling them goods, etc.
_are you being served, madam?
_that's the restaurant where they refused to serve giles because he was so rude.

children.name: flog x
children.definition: flog/flɒgǁflɑːg/  british informal to sell something, especially something that is oflow qualityor that has somethingwrongwith it:
examples: ▪ there was a man at the market who was flogging watches for £10 each.
flog somebody something
▪ don’t let him flog you his car -- he’s had endless trouble with it.

children.name: peddle x
children.definition: peddle/ˈpedl/  to sell goods, usually things that are cheap, especially by going from place to place rather than selling them in a shop:
examples: bán rong
▪ street vendors peddled flowers and candles.
▪ belloni started her bakery business by peddling her homemade bread to local stores.

children.name: deal in x
children.definition: deal in/ˈdiːl ɪn/  to buy and sell a particular kind of goods as part of your business:
examples: ▪ the gallery deals mostly in paintings but they do sometimes sell photographs.
▪ tax agents are visiting more than 5,000 businesses that deal in expensive items such as cars, boats, and jewels.

children.name: flog x
children.definition: flog/flɒgǁflɑːg/  britishinformalto sell something, especially something that is of low quality or that has something wrong with it:
examples: ▪ there was a man at the market who was flogging watches for £10 each.
flog somebody something
▪ don’t let him flog you his car -- he’s had endless trouble with it.

children.name: peddle x
children.definition: peddle/ˈpedl/  to sell goods, usually things that are cheap, especially by going from place to place rather than selling them in a shop:
examples: ▪ street vendors peddled flowers and candles.
▪ belloni started her bakery business by peddling her homemade bread to local stores.
peddleverb[ t ]mainly disapproving bán rong; bán rao
to sell things, especially by taking them to different places
_these products are generally peddled (from) door to door.
_he travels around, peddling hiswares.

children.name: trading x
children.definition: trading/ˈtreɪdɪŋ/  the activity of selling goods or shares in companies:
examples: ▪ trading started briskly on the new york stock exchange this morning.
stop/cease trading
▪ the company ran out of money and was forced to cease trading.

children.name: service b1
children.definition: servicenoundealing with customer
examples: [ u ] the act of dealing with a customer in a shop, resturant or hotel by taking their order, showing or selling them goods, etc.
_the only trouble with this café is that the service is so slow.

children.name: when all of sth has been sold
sell out b2
children.definition: sell out/ˌsel ˈaʊt/  if a shop, ticket office etc sells out ofgoodsortickets, or if goods or tickets sell out, all of them are sold so there are no more available:
examples: được bán hết
▪ i went to the store to get some bread but they had sold out.
▪ sunday newspapers often sell out by 10 o'clock.
sell out of : bán sạch, bán hết
▪ they opened at 8 o'clock, and by 8.30 they had sold out of tickets for the big game.
be sold outwhen all the tickets for a performance or sports event have been sold
▪ we couldn’t get tickets anywhere - the show was completely sold out.
sell outphrasal verbsell allbán hết
ifa supply of somethingsells out, there is no more of that thing to buy
_the first issue of the magazine sold out within two days.

children.name: be a sell-out u
children.definition: be a sell-out/biː ə ˈsel aʊt/  if a play, football game, concert etc is a sell-out, it is very popular and all the tickets for it have been sold:
examples: ▪ the band’s european tour was a sell-out.
sell-out crowd
▪ the mariners beat the angels in front of a sell-out crowd.

children.name: out of stock b2
children.definition: be out of stock/biː ˌaʊt əv ˈstɒkǁ-ˈstɑːk/  if a product or the shop selling the product is out of stock, the shop does not have any of that product available now, because they have sold all of it:
examples: hết hàng
▪ the scooters are popular and are often out of stock.
▪ we’re out of stock, but we can put one on order for you.

children.name: be booked up/fully booked u
children.definition: be booked up/fully booked/biː ˌbʊkt ˈʌp, ˌfʊli ˈbʊkt/  if a hotel, restaurant, or organized trip somewhere is booked up or fully booked, all the places have been bought and there are no more available:
examples: đã được đặt hết
▪ flights to the us are all booked up this time of year.
▪ popular campsites are fully booked on weekends for most of the summer.

children.name: to sell sth to the person who offers the most money
auction x
children.definition: auction alsoauctionoff/ˈɔːkʃən, ˌɔːkʃən ˈɒf/
examples: bán đấu giá
▪ one of the beatles’ guitars is being auctioned for charity.
▪ the contents of the house were auctioned to pay off the family’s debts.
auctionverb[ t ] auction something offbán đấu giá
to sell something in a public auction
_the stamps will be auctioned tomorrow.
_the family is auctioning(off)its art collection.

children.name: put sth up for auction c1
children.definition: put something upfor auction/ˌpʊt something ˌʌp fər ˈɔːkʃən/  to arrange for something be sold at a public meeting to the person who offers to pay the most money:
examples: đưa ra bán đấu giá
▪ after months trying to sell the farm, they decided to put it up for auction.
▪ one of the world’s finest collections of vintage cars is to be put up for auction.

children.name: come/go under the hammer x
children.definition: come/go under the hammer/ˌkʌm, ˌgəʊ ʌndəʳ ðə ˈhæməʳ/ informalif something comes or goes under the hammer, especially something valuable such as a famous painting, it is sold at an auction:
examples: được đưa ra bán đấu giá
▪ a collection of prints and paintings by picasso came under the hammer at sotheby’s yesterday.

children.name: auction c1
children.definition: auction/ˈɔːkʃən/  a public meeting at which things are sold to the person who offers to pay the most money:
examples: ▪ the buyer did not attend the auction, but sent a representative to place the bids.
hold an auction
▪ sotheby’s decided to hold auctions in japan twice a year.
at (an) auction
▪ bikes that have not been claimed by the owners will be sold at a public auction january 11.
▪ how much do you think the painting would fetch at auction?
auctionnoun[ c or u ] cuộc bán đấu giá
a usually public sale of goods or property, where people make higher and higherbids (= offers of money) for each thing, until the thing is sold to the person who will pay most
_a furniture auction
_they'reholdingan auctionofjewellery on thursday.
_the painting will be soldat/uk alsobyauction next week.
_the house and its contents are beingput up forauction.

children.name: to make sth available for people to buy
put sth on the market x
children.definition: put something on the market alsocome/go on the market/ˌpʊt something ɒn ðə ˈmɑːʳkt, ˌkʌm, ˌgəʊ ɒn ðə ˈmɑːʳkt/
examples: tung ra thị trường
▪ we put our house on the market last september and we still haven’t sold it.
▪ the drug came on the market in the late 1990s and has been widely prescribed.
▪ the car will probably sell for around $50,000 when it goes on the market.
▪ most wines are left to mature before they are put on the market.

children.name: put sth up for sale a2
children.definition: put something up for sale/ˌpʊt something ʌp fəʳ ˈseɪl/  to make something such as a house, business, or piece of land available for people to buy:
examples: đưa ra bán
▪ the historic property has been put up for sale.
▪ after the merger, parts of the business are likely to be put up for sale.

children.name: bring out b2
children.definition: bring out/ˌbrɪŋ ˈaʊt/if a company brings out a new product that they have made, they make it available for people to buy:
examples: xuất bản, phát hành, tung ra
bring out something
▪ kodak brought out a camera which stores up to 100 images on a computer disc.
bring something out
▪ the two cookbooks have sold well, and doubleday is bringing them out in new paperback editions.
bringsthoutphrasal verb[ m ]produce
to produce something to sell to the public
_they keep bringing out smaller phones.

children.name: launch b2
children.definition: launch/lɔːntʃ/  if a company launches a new product, they publicly announce, especially with a lot of advertising, that it is available for people to buy:
examples: tung ra , ra mắt
▪ fiat launched a tiny ‘city car’ especially for europe’s narrow, crowded streets.
▪ fezza, the clothes designer, launched his first collection in 1980.

children.name: release b2
children.definition: release/rɪˈliːs/  if a company releases arecordorfilm, it makes it available for people to buy or see:
examples: phát hành, tung ra
▪ her new album will be released at the end of the month.
▪ carrey’s new comedy is due to be released in the us very soon.
release[countable noun] something that has been released::
▪ the band’s latest release record that has been released▪ should be in the stores friday.
phim ảnh

children.name: publish b1
children.definition: publish/ˈpʌblɪʃ/  to print a book, magazine, or newspaper and make it available for people to buy:
examples: xuất bản, phát hành
▪ ladybird publish books for young children.
▪ amateur photographer is published every tuesday.
▪ rowling’s latest harry potter novel sold millions of copies as soon as it was published.
publication/ˌpʌblɪˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun] when something is published::
▪ since the publication of her book, she’s received thousands of letters from women who have had similar experiences.
publisher[countable noun] a company that publishes books::
▪ none of the big uk publishers wanted to do a paperback version of the book.

children.name: take sth off the market u
children.definition: take something off the market/ˌteɪk something ɒf ðə ˈmɑːʳkt/  if a company takes a product off the market, it stops producing it and shops stop selling it:
examples: rút khỏi thị trường
▪ the mineral water was taken off the market while tests were being made.
▪ sales of the newspaper were so poor that it was taken off the market within a couple of months.
▪ the federal drug administration has said that all products containing the additive must be taken off the market immediately.

children.name: withdraw c1
children.definition: withdraw/wɪðˈdrɔː, wɪθ-/  if a shop or a company withdraws a product, it makes it unavailable for people to buy by removing it from shops:
examples: thu hồi
▪ newsagents across the country have withdrawn the magazine after numerous complaints from women’s groups.
▪ after two children had been hurt, the company was forced to withdraw the toy from store shelves.
withdraw something from sale
▪ christmas decorations were withdrawn from sale yesterday following a fire-risk warning.
withdrawal[uncountable noun]
▪ stores have agreed to the withdrawal of the offending videos.

children.name: recall x
children.definition: recall/rɪˈkɔːl/if acompanyrecalls a product, they ask all the shops that sell it and the people that have bought it to send it back to them for checking, because there may be somethingwrongwith it:
examples: rút lại, thu hồi
▪ thousands of car baby-seats have had to be recalled after a fault was discovered in the safety harness.
▪ the company voluntarily recalled about 11,000 of the devices to check them for defects.
recall/rɪˈkɔːlǁrɪˈkɔːl, ˈriːkɔːl/ [uncountable noun]
▪ they put a notice in the press ordering the recall of all the baby food that might have been contaminated.

children.name: get rid of sth b1
children.definition: get rid ofsth tống khứ
examples: to sell an old or unwanted possession
_have you managed to get rid of your old volvo yet?

children.name: sale b2
children.definition: salenounsell sự bán, việc bán
examples: [ c or u ] an act of exchanging something for money
_the saleofcigarettes/alcohol is forbidden.
_the building company get 10% commission on each house sale.
_i haven'tmadea sale all morning.
_they'll drop the price rather thanlosethe sale.

children.name: retail c1
children.definition: retailnoun (sự)bán lẻ; việc bán lẻ
examples: the activity of selling goods to the public, usually in small quantities
_the job is open to applicants with over two years' experience in retail.
_the clothing company has six retailoutlets(= shops) in south-easternaustralia.
_$13 off the manufacturer's recommended retailprice

children.name: the sale of sth b2
children.definition: the sale of something/ðə ˈseɪl əv something/  when something is sold:
examples: ▪ the rebels are using money from the sale of drugs to buy weapons.
▪ the law prohibits the sale and consumption of alcohol on unlicensed premises.

children.name: telesales/ telemarketing u
children.definition: telesalesnoun (ustelemarketing) bán hàng qua điện thoại
examples: the advertising or selling of goods or servicesby telephone

children.name: retail at/for sth
children.definition: retail at/forsth đượcbán lẻvới giá
examples: to be soldat a particular price
_this model of computer is retailing at £650.

children.name: salesmanship
children.definition: noun nghệ thuật bán hàng
examples: skill in selling
_clever salesmanship can persuade you to buy things you don't really want.

children.name: resell
children.definition: verbresold,resold bán lại (cái gì mình đã mua cho một người khác)
examples: to sell something which you previously bought
_he buys up run-down properties, fixes them up and resells them.
